author: Akshay Saklani
text: I wonder if copilot could've picked that up

author: Franco Aguilera
text: I don't think so, obfuscated code behind a convention name (.svn), I don't think it would have been able to notice

author: Akshay Saklani
text: it would have cleaned it off thinking its a typo I think but I guess repositories need to be monitored from now on

author: Niko Dunixi
text: I mean... you have the server and more or less the format they expect.... Time to see if they can handle extraneous load and sanitize their inputs??

author: Franco Aguilera
text:
Yes, they actually removed it, but I think it was lucky that the news got out. here you can see a copy of the original repo
https://github.com/Kotivskyi/ChallengerKnight

author: Ong H.
text: Niko Dunixi The real coding interview 😂

author: Anastasiia Drachuk
text:
That’s impressive 😬 
Could you please give some practical advice for beginners, how to secure ourselves from similar problems? 
I’m not sure that I’ve recognized the trick even if I reviewed the code, especially on live-code-interview.

author: Franco Aguilera
text: Always, no matter how brief, inspect the code before running it, whenever you can run the application in a safe environment (virtual machine, or some partition you have for sandbox), and always try to keep yourself updated on the subject

author: Kevin Guanche Darias
text:
Anastasiia Drachuk They are basically uploading all the passwords or caches of your web browsers, also your crypto wallet, even if you don't store passwords they could access your accounts by using your own opened "remember me" sessions

The hack is probably done by a newbie, because it would be much harder to detect, if they randomly cloned a random npm package with a changed char and used that as npm dependency... from now onwards I will be very paranoid from interview provided repos, and Would always run them inside a docker container, fortunately I'm happy in my current company... but I take the issue in serious consideration for any possible future

author: Getnet Demil ™
text: Wow, I'm utterly flabbergasted by your experience! It's shocking how common scams are, especially in the tech space. Your vigilance in spotting that hidden code is impressive, and I'm glad you caught it in time! Thanks for sharing this vital lesson with all of us.

author: Franco Aguilera
text: thanks to you for the comment 👍

author: Elyer Maldonado
text: Pero miren el tamaño de esos huevos!

author: Franco Aguilera
text: Elyer Maldonado muchas gracias por tu mensaje Ely, un abrazo muy grande, espero que andes muy bien amigo 😃

author: Elyer Maldonado
text: Franco Aguilera Gracias querido! Te mando un abrazote también!

author: Abdullah Khurram
text:
There are some paths like exodus.wallet in App data in the code you've shown

Exodus is a crypto wallet and it could be a crypto clipping scam.

In crypto clipping, multiple addresses or hashes of hacker's wallet are stored in the victim's computer. So, when the victim tries to do any crypto transactions, this script replaces the destination address with hacker's address in the memory buffer and you'll end up sending money to the hacker.

author: Abdullah Khurram
text: Francisco Javier Williams Monardez Yes

author: Ikenna Uwakwe
text:
Happened to me one time during which I entered into a weeks-long Coding challenge along with about 30 other developers (hard to peg a number as the figure was incremental over time), only the said company wasn’t looking to steal our crypto rather they were stealing participants’ GPU to mine crypto on the fly. 

Just like you, we all were excited to jump on this new challenge as they targeted mid-senior level developers from all over Africa, hence, we were all excited to showcase our skillsets as we compared them against other industry professionals. What tipped me off was when they started kicking out people for no reason, entering new participants everyday. Even worse, was that the codebase required us to grant the company’s remote server access to our PC resources at all times.

And then a friend of mine who was recently dropped started complaining about having his PC lag ever since. Only then did I feel the need to conduct an in-depth research on the company to see what exactly they were into. And just as I had predicted, they were into crypto mining using third-party GPUs from remote users all over the word.

I mean who has better PC resources than creatives like programmers and graphics designers?

author: José Joaquín Núñez Vallejos
text: Ikenna Uwakwe steal GPU, brilliant

author: Pietro Boccaletto, PhD
text:
Hi, I’ve quickly deobfuscated and analyzed the code. If you’ve executed it, you should not only change your passwords but also deauthenticate or invalidate active sessions (e.g., cookies) across all your connected accounts. This script compromises your browser profiles and session data, which could allow unauthorized access to your accounts. Additionally, I recommend closely monitoring access to all your online platforms.

Here’s what the code does:

Steals browser profiles, including cookies, saved passwords, browsing history, and other sensitive data.

Extracts cryptocurrency wallets.

Retrieves system passwords stored in keychains.


Furthermore, in the final lines, the script attempts to locate a Python executable and download a file from a remote server. This could be (pending further investigation) part of a persistence mechanism allowing the attacker to maintain control of your machine.

I strongly advise you to disconnect the system from the Internet immediately, consult a Cybersecurity specialist, and consider reformatting the computer to ensure it is secure.

Stay vigilant and safe!

author: Kevin Guanche Darias
text: Pietro Boccaletto, PhD Srr, I wrote my comment without noticing, you already explained the exact impact of the js script, still we are unaware of the Python part

author: Abdulhakeem Muhammed
text:
I see. I have been getting A LOT of job requests here on LinkedIn from supposed HR individuals.
Either they refer me to another supposed PM or they send me an interview task directly.

In both cases, we keep in contact for so long till I completed the task and send videos or pics as the case may be, immediately after that I get 'Ghosted'.

One such occasion, I was told to install 'anydesk' and give complete access to the PM, which I did.

But what trips me off was that he went and started checking my other messages on.

I believeshould give a way to report these set of people in order to prevent innocent hardworking people from been scammed in the name of job opportunities.

author: Vladimir Goncharov
text: Luis Francisco Chávez Hita Romero they are busy with intrusive spam offers suggesting to get LinkedIn Premium

author: Laurin B.
text: Line wrapping is your friend here! This is a general problem with many questionable repositories on github. Especially with python projects already seen several times. They use excessive indents or deeply nested functions/classes to hide the malicious code far down in the file, making it unlikely to be noticed during a casual inspection. The malicious logic can be disguised using techniques such as base64 encoding, dynamically constructed Python code (exec, eval), or inline comments that break readability.
